Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project resides in its novel approach to transferring and capturing knowledge and organizing it for application. The art of learning is the keystone to society's arch of success. From the most complex chemical reaction to running a government every aspect of humanity has been based on the sharing and passing of knowledge - always refining it along the way. The proposed mobile software product, a multidimensional method acquirer and perfector, seeks to standardize all regions and echelons of understanding, bridging the gaps between the professional, academic, public, and even private sectors, connections which will blaze new pathways in scientific novelty and commercial collaboration.

This I-Corps project focuses on addressing the pains and gains of learning in stressful and demanding research environments. The Method Catcher is a smartphone software designed to intake any set of instructions and standardize it into a dynamic and customized .inscript file type. The software adapts a series of user recorded media into editable, scannable, publishable, and pedagogical stepwise navigations of time, environment, material, and reason to accomplish any task: be it sandwich-making or neurosurgery. Research methodology is usually transferred via written methods sections between studies, and hierarchical pedagogy within studies. The proposed technology includes method walkthroughs: seamlessly instantiating adaptable stepwise protocol capture by transforming photographic sequences of - say - surgical demos into sharable, completely replicable protocols - exportable to bar code stickers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

Performance_Institution.Name: Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research is slow.

Inscriptures® - a company wielding smartphone apps to improve scientific replicability by 50% - wants to change this. Funded by NSF, Inscriptures' cofounders conducted over 155 customer discovery interviews across New York City, Baltimore, Chicago, Aspen, Washington DC, Houston, Seattle, Los Angelos, San Franscico, Boston, Newark, and Philadelphia. The customer discovery process was so successful, Inscriptures® continued a self-funded international session in Barcelona, Tel Aviv, the Yucatan, Singapore, and Tokyo.

After collecting resounding evidence from Contract Research Organization managers, both domestic and abroad, there is resounding need for lighting-fast research communication platforms. The entire pharmaceutical trial process is based on 300+ page, text-only protocols handoffs "no one has the time to read", a quote echoed across 78 interviews. Moreover the Trial Master File (TMF) system carrying said handoffs is "outdated", and "unintentially killing people" with its impediment to drug trial progress. Many human trials are based off published translational method sections, shortened text blurbs "impossibly communicating years of hard work", leaving 90% of trials to be "regurgitated drugs". A "recipe" app with the panache of Snapchat would revolutionize the "already horrifically innacurate" research method sections - as decribed by one of Cell 's own chief editors. If the app moreover added QR code functionality, Johns Hopkins Board Advisor Harry Goldberg stated "such technology would permenantly change science, and the way science is done." 

Not only did these cries evidence a problem-solution fit, but a resounding product-market fit. Given the ubiquity of a smartphone, many healthcare organizations already spend up to $30,000 annually on TMF systems that fail to meet their needs: sizing the market to be $1.6 Trillion annually. Interviews at with major research hospital CFOs and CIOs - including Stanford, Johns Hopkins, and Lurie Children's Hospital - moreover revealed information concerning a ripe market: 

Relationally, customers will be acquired at a $78,000 Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC), kept and grown by user-profiles at a Long Term Value (LTV) of $300,000, yielding the overarching LTV:CAC ratio of 3.85:1. Software will be sold via licensed contractual models for $100,000. Included in the above calculations are costs: supporting server partnerships, associated legal protections, and key human resources. Proposed partnerships with Cell - after interviewing Editor April Pawluk - Massachusetts Biotechnology Council - Liaison Lucie Rochard - and CRO consortiums reach to available market opportunity.

Though Inscriptures® was not subsequently awarded NSF's SBIR award, we remain devoted to developing said groundbreaking technology. The I-Corps process was a gateway to create economic machinery with both societal benefit and lucrative outlook.

Thus: we are busy at work so next time something akin to COVID-19 breaks out - scientists can finally leverage the perfect, photographic, communicative memories of their smartphones.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/27/2020
Modified by: Adin M Aoki
